title: 106_s148
content:
The Act is titled the "Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Act". Congress finds that approximately 500 bird species in the United States migrate among countries, with many neotropical migratory bird populations in decline due to habitat loss and degradation. The decline in neotropical migratory bird populations is primarily due to habitat loss and degradation, including pollution and contamination. Conservation efforts require the commitment of all countries along their migration routes, and initiatives can be strengthened through increased coordination. The purposes of this Act are to perpetuate healthy populations of neotropical migratory birds, support conservation initiatives in the United States, Latin America, and the Caribbean, and provide financial resources for international cooperation. SEC. 4. DEFINITIONS.

    In this Act:
        (1) Account.--The term ``Account'' means the Neotropical 
    Migratory Bird Conservation Account established by section 9(a).
        (2) Conservation.--The term ``conservation'' means methods necessary to ensure long-term viability of neotropical migratory bird species, including protection, habitat management, research, law enforcement, and community outreach.
        (3) Secretary.--The term ``Secretary'' means the Secretary of 
    the Interior. The Secretary will establish a program to provide financial assistance for projects promoting the conservation of neotropical migratory birds. Project proposals can be submitted by various entities, including individuals, government agencies, and international organizations. The Act establishes a program for financial assistance for projects conserving neotropical migratory bird species. Project proposals must include details like project purpose, qualifications of individuals involved, and funding estimates. The project should enhance bird conservation in the United States, Latin America, or the Caribbean. The project proposal must demonstrate how it will enhance the conservation of neotropical migratory bird species, ensure local public participation, consult with relevant authorities, respect local historic and cultural resources, promote sustainable programs, and provide any necessary information for evaluation. The project proposal must promote sustainable, long-term programs for neotropical migratory birds and provide necessary information for evaluation. Recipients must submit periodic reports to the Secretary for project progress assessment. The Federal share of project costs should not exceed 25%, and the non-Federal share must not come from Federal grant programs. The non-Federal share for a project should not exceed 25% and cannot be derived from any Federal grant program. In the United States, the non-Federal share must be paid in cash, while in foreign countries, it can be paid in cash or in kind. SEC. 6. DUTIES OF THE SECRETARY. The Secretary will develop guidelines for project proposals, encourage submissions from wildlife management authorities, select proposals meeting requirements, and implement the Act. The Secretary shall support and coordinate efforts to conserve neotropical migratory bird species by facilitating meetings, exchanging information, entering agreements, and coordinating activities with existing conservation projects. An advisory group may be convened to assist in carrying out the Act. The Secretary may convene an advisory group consisting of individuals from public and private organizations actively involved in conserving neotropical migratory birds. The advisory group must hold open meetings for public participation, provide timely notice of meetings, and keep minutes of each meeting. The Secretary must provide timely notice of advisory group meetings and keep minutes available to the public. The advisory group is exempt from the Federal Advisory Committee Act. The Secretary is required to submit a report to Congress by October 1, 2002, detailing the results and effectiveness of the program under the Act, along with recommendations for improvement and whether the program should continue. Additionally, there is a provision for the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account. Establishment of the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account within the Multinational Species Conservation Fund of the Treasury to receive donations and appropriations. The Secretary of the Treasury can use the funds for program implementation, with a limit of 3% or $80,000 for administrative expenses. The Secretary may expend up to 3% or $80,000 from the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account for administrative expenses. Donations can be accepted and used for implementing the program, with funds transferred to the Treasury for deposit into the Account. Authorization of appropriations for the Neotropical Migratory Bird Conservation Account is set at $5,000,000 annually from 2001 to 2005, with a requirement that at least 75 percent of the funds be used for projects outside the United States.
